Honey and its effects on breast cancer

  • In conclusion, the combination of ginger and Gelam honey may be an effective chemopreventive and therapeutic strategy for inducing the death of colon cancer cells.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • Nutrition Journal. Published 2015.
  • The findings indicate that TH could afford protection of non-cancerous cells from the toxic effects of tamoxifen by increasing the efficiency of DNA repair mechanism in these cells.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine. Published 2014.
  • The findings indicate that TH could afford protection of non-cancerous cells from the toxic effects of tamoxifen by increasing the efficiency of DNA repair mechanism in these cells.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine. Published 2014-03-19.
  • These data support that honeys induced apoptosis in HL-60 cells through a ROS-independent cell death pathway. Moreover, our findings indicate that the antiproliferative and apoptotic effects of honey varied according to the floral origin and the phenolic content.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • Pharmacognosy Magazine. Published Jul-Sep 2013.
  • It might be concluded that honey may cause cell death in the ACHN cells, in which apoptosis plays an important role. Most of the drugs used in the cancer treatment are apoptotic inducers, hence apoptotic nature of honey is considered vital. Therefore, it prompted us to investigate honey as a potential candidate for renal cancer treatment.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • Pharmacognosy Magazine. Published Jan-Mar 2011.
